comments:
When entering a project name into the New Project Wizard, the user is issued a
warning message in the banner at the top of the dialog if the new project name
is an *exact* match of an existing project in the workspace. If the user
provides a duplicate name that differs in case alone, then the warning is not
displayed.

I.e.

Scenario 1. (ProjectA == ProjectA) => Warning
Scenario 2. (ProjectA != projecta) => No warning

The current implementation is okay for Linux and Unix since the file system is
case sensitive, but not on Windows where the file system is case insensitive.
(i.e. ProjectA == projecta).

The following error is dumped to the .log file under scenario 2:

!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 275 May 03, 2004 09:43:35.109
!MESSAGE A resource exists with a different case: /ProjA.

I recall this being reported before.... This is not a CDT issue, this behavior
applies to all project types.

Ok, but you may note that the JDT offers the following message under the same
circumstances: "The specified external location already exists. If a project is
created in this location, the wizard will automatically try to detect existing
sources and class files and configure the classpath appropriately."

I'll let someone else decide if the CDT should do something similar...

But then gives the same error after you apply.

The message about already existing project is something completely different
then what this bug is about.

traces.message: A resource exists with a different case: /ProjA.
